subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Basics of eCommerce: How to Sell Online
headline: Learn how to successfully market and sell goods online and grow your brand in this free online eCommerce course.
description: Are you an aspiring online trader or do you want to sharpen your current eCommerce skills? This course explores the basics of eCommerce and provides proven digital marketing, selling and distribution strategies. We explain how to set sensible prices, package your goods attractively and safely and select a suitable payment service. We also outline how to source goods and select a suitable manufacturing partner who can streamline your processes.
courseDescription:
Online commercial activity is called ‘eCommerce’ and sales on sites like eBay and Amazon are booming. Do you want to join this growing trend and start trading online or have you already begun but need insider tips to improve your profit margins? If so, this commerce course is for you.

We begin by discussing pricing as your business can suffer serious losses or even go bankrupt if goods are priced too high or too low. We discuss this issue in depth and provide effective pricing strategies by identifying ‘break-even’ prices that don’t scare off potential customers or cause you losses by aiming too low. The course then explains how to select the right shipping partners to ensure that items are safely delivered to customers on time.

Next, we establish the importance of effective packaging that creates consumer interest and excitement. We explore marketing principles to help you package goods and build your brand with satisfied customers. Finally, the course teaches you how to select and set up appropriate payment services that allow global transactions. Enrol in this eCommerce course and learn now and become a successful online vendor.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Compute the different costs involved in getting your products to your customers.
    • Identify how to package your products effectively before shipment.
    • Select the shipping partner that is right for you when planning to deliver your goods.
    • Describe the concept of effective packaging and apply it in a way that will promote your brand.
    • Recognise when you may hire a manufacturer and determine which manufacturer is right for you.
    • Define the term payment service provider (PSP) and how to set one up for online payments. 

  • Case Study

  • Imagine Gina’s Greens, a plant store that specializes in creating specific soil varieties for different species of plants. Gina’s a great botanist but an inexperienced business owner, and he’s not 100% sure how to come up with prices for his soils.

    Some of them have to be refined in a laboratory, while others are just what he digs out of his own land. The soil for Barley is proving particularly challenging to put a price on.
  • At this point, Gina just wants to bury his head in the ground and forget all about it.

    But since becoming a plant isn’t really an option for him, what should his next move be? How should Gina figure out what to charge for his products?

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Research and rational calculations are definitely the right way to go here. That way, Gina can select a price that keeps his business running and, hopefully, some profit in his pocket.

  • Case Study

  • Imagine you’ve got a business selling second-hand items. You’ve just found an amazing collection of glass sculptures featuring koalas and pandas. After posting pictures of the sculptures online, it turns out people from all over want their own piece of your sculpted glass art.

    But these are delicate items, and the last thing you want are these cute and cuddly animals becoming shards of glass. As you contemplate how to ship these classics, you find you have a few options on how to pack them up. But which makes the most sense? Let’s find out.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Question: Which of these boxes above is better packed? The one on the right or the one on the left?
    You're right! The one on the right is a model package.

  • Case Study

  • Case Study

  • Bryan's Robotics is a new business that sells cute automatons online.

    People are excited to have a tiny bot in their house, and orders are piling in.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Now, Bryan knows some people think of robots as being sort of unfeeling, and he wants buyers to love his business. So he’s put a lot of work into creating wonderful products, building his online store, and training his customer service reps. But packaging’s a different story.

    Bryan kind of feels like once people have purchased a product, he’s fulfilled his part of the bargain, and he can just send it out to them. Seriously–do people really care that much about packaging?

    Packaging isn’t simply about boxes and tapes. It's a fundamental part of your relationship with your customers.

  • Case Study

  • Case Study

  • Picture Justin, who’s found a revolutionary clothing material that can regulate people’s body temperatures. He knows this could completely change the clothing industry. He’s thought a lot about starting a business, down to knowing exactly what he wants his clothes to look like.

    But while Justin has the formula for the fabric, he doesn’t have the skills, time, or machinery to make all the clothing styles he thinks he’ll need.
  • Justin attempted to make them himself.

    Sadly, he feels like everything it takes to create these clothes is a real nightmare.

    He starts to lose faith in this business.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • So, what would be the best course of action for him to take? Should he quit? Or should he find someone who can help him solve these problems he has encountered–a manufacturing partner?

  • Case Study

    Sadly, he feels like everything it takes to create these clothes is a real nightmare.

    He starts to lose faith in this business.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • So, what would be the best course of action for him to take? Should he quit? Or should he find someone who can help him solve these problems he has encountered–a manufacturing partner?

  • Give Attention to Payment Methods

  • You probably know that selling your products to new international markets can take a lot of planning and a good understanding of cultural differences. But it’s easy to forget that cultural differences can include how people like to pay for things. 
  • Credit cards are the most popular form of online payment in some countries. But in others, alternative payment methods are the norm.

    Online bank transfers, mobile websites, cash-based payment options, and other alternative methods give people a fast, easy way to buy online.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • They’re also great for those who might not have a credit card or bank account. Knowing how your customers like to pay is important. 30% of online global shoppers say they might not complete a purchase if a site doesn’t offer their preferred pay method.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this course, you have learned that:
    • When pricing your products, you should pay attention to the costs involved in getting your products into the hands of your customers. These costs are:
      1. Cost of your materials: the stuff used to make your stuff,
      2. Labour costs: the time and money it takes you and your team to work on your products,
      3. Additional expenses: List every operational cost that impacts this product.
    • To find the break-even price of your product—the lowest price you can sell it at and not lose money, you should add your labour, materials, and expenses together to find your total production cost for the item. Once you know how much it costs to make your item, consider the amount of the item you can sell. Then, divide the total production cost by this amount.
    • You should use bubble wrap or other lightweight packing material to provide protection and give fragile items a strong, sturdy box.
    • Effective packaging is divided into 3 parts: shipping packaging, product packaging, and extras, and all 3 of these impact how your customers experience your brand. Treating each of them with equal importance lets you create a final package that sets your brand apart.
